author: JuliaRegistrator

comments.body:
Your `new package` pull request does not meet the guidelines for auto-merging. Please make sure that you have read the [General registry README](https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General/blob/master/README.md) and the [AutoMerge guidelines](https://juliaregistries.github.io/RegistryCI.jl/stable/guidelines/). The following guidelines were not met:

- Repo URL does not end with /name.jl.git, where name is the package name
- The following dependencies do not have a `[compat]` entry that is upper-bounded and only includes a finite number of breaking releases: ComponentArrays, DataFrames, Distributions, OrdinaryDiffEq, Parameters, PrecompileTools, StaticArrays, StatsBase
- I was not able to load the package (i.e. `import Hydra` failed). See the AutoMerge logs for details.

Note that the guidelines are only required for the pull request to be merged automatically. However, it is **strongly recommended** to follow them, since otherwise the pull request needs to be manually reviewed and merged by a human.

After you have fixed the AutoMerge issues, simply retrigger Registrator, which will automatically update this pull request. You do not need to change the version number in your `Project.toml` file (unless of course the AutoMerge issue is that you skipped a version number, in which case you should change the version number).

If you do not want to fix the AutoMerge issues, please post a comment explaining why you would like this pull request to be manually merged. Then, send a message to the `#pkg-registration` channel in the [Julia Slack](https://julialang.org/slack/) to ask for help. Include a link to this pull request.

Since you are registering a new package, please make sure that you have also read the package naming guidelines: https://pkgdocs.julialang.org/v1/creating-packages/#Package-naming-guidelines



---
If you want to prevent this pull request from being auto-merged, simply leave a comment. If you want to post a comment without blocking auto-merging, you must include the text `[noblock]` in your comment. You can edit blocking comments, adding `[noblock]` to them in order to unblock auto-merging.
<!-- [noblock] -->
<!---
this_is_the_single_automerge_comment
--->

Thank you for submitting your package! However, please make sure to add some documentation before registering. [At the very least](https://discourse.julialang.org/t/when-does-it-make-sense-to-post-a-new-package-to-the-julia-repository/108701/4), that would be a small usage example in the README.

I did see your note

> Examples, tests, and documentation will follow

but at least a minimal version of these is necessary for the registration to be merged. You don't need a *full* online documentation yet, but the package must be in a state where it can be used by others, with enough information in the README to get started.

P.S.: The name similarity to `Hydro` is a bit troublesome, but I'd give it a pass. Arguably, `Hydro` should have been flagged as a bad name when it was registered two years ago. Of course "Hydra" is also a pretty generic / popular (one would think) name, but as far as I'm concerned, it's okay as a "less systematic name". And for those, first come, first serve.

> Thank you for submitting your package! However, please make sure to add some documentation before registering. [At the very least](https://discourse.julialang.org/t/when-does-it-make-sense-to-post-a-new-package-to-the-julia-repository/108701/4), that would be a small usage example in the README.
> 

Thanks for the note, I will add some information to the README asap.

> P.S.: The name similarity to `Hydro` is a bit troublesome, but I'd give it a pass. Arguably, `Hydro` should have been flagged as a bad name when it was registered two years ago. Of course "Hydra" is also a pretty generic / popular (one would think) name, but as far as I'm concerned, it's okay as a "less systematic name". And for those, first come, first serve.

Thanks too for the leniency regarding the package name. I see the point in providing more specific names and was surprised that `Hydra`did not exist yet (after struggling to find a better one and the most obvious `DynamicEnergyBudgets` already exists).
Closing in favor of https://github.com/JuliaRegistries/General/pull/108080, but you have to address “Repo URL does not end with /name.jl.git, where name is the package name” first and foremost
